title: Metal type, Wood, Chiselled, Engraved with Swashes and Shadow
content:
Help much appreciated please...  
Matt

Font: 

 Chorus Girl 

Solved By: 

 [Mike F](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/typophile.com/user/3368 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [image.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/typophile.com/files/image_127.jpg) | 83.99 KB |
author: Theory Unit

comments.content:
Might help if you gave some hint as to the nature of the image, logo, menu, old book etc and an approximate date.  
At first glance this looks like a "Latin" type such as Etienne [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/etienne/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/etienne/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/etienne/") Latin CT [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-ct/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-ct/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-ct/") ITC Barcelona [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/barcelona/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/barcelona/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/barcelona/") or Spike [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/quadrat/spike/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/quadrat/spike/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/quadrat/spike/") with a shadow line and coat-hook ornaments pasted amidships.  
This is not to say that someone has not packaged this mish mash as a font. Could have been done by a Victorian typemaker with little imagination or a similarly changed modern designer.  
Compare it with the somewhat similar, but much better designed Algerian [http://www.myfonts.com/search/algerian/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/algerian/fonts/ "http://www.myfonts.com/search/algerian/fonts/")  
Don

The font is Chorus Girl and the only source I'm aware of is on the CD bundled with the [24 Victorian Display Fonts CD-ROM and Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.amazon.com/Victorian-Display-Fonts-CD-ROM-Electronic/dp/0486999564/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1394897721&sr=8-1&keywords=24+fonts+victorian). Dover stopped making and selling these several years ago, so I've linked to one possible solution (just make sure the CD is intact).

This font has been digitized by Dan X Solo for Dover Publications Inc. under the name of **Chorus Girl**. Should be available [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350/http:/www.barnesandnoble.com/w/24-victorian-display-fonts-dan-x-solo/1003081724).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141011012350im_/http:/typophile.com/files/sw_avms_token-rush_logo_3685.png)

I stand corrected. This is an inept Victorian design, rather than a modern mish mash. Looking at the full alphabet, I see no reason to modify my critical appraisal. It's still a somewhat standard Latin with discordant coat hooks pasted on -- presumably so the chorus girls have someplace to hang their costumes after the show.  
Don

I agree, Don. Spot-on appraisal.

By the way, Matt. The font was a bit manually stretched (so as to allow for easier hanging of costumes).

Please don't get me wrong, I AM a fan of Victorian ornate typefaces when they are imaginative and well executed. But this one is so uninspired and clunky that it gives a bad name to the whole genre.  
Don
The basic issue is that the "hooks" make no sence.

Thank you all very much. I had almost given up so you've made a frustrated designer very happy. Thanks again.  
Cheers,  
Matt
